So am I bullish?

Not really. I am cautious about the crypto market in the short term.

But I am cautious due to poor macro, miners potentially dumping, and more contagion uncertainty.

Not because of Mt. Gox. 

(7/7)

Third, we assume that they might sell instantly.

Well, think about it this way. [Not by their will of course], but these creditors saw BTC go from sub-$10,000 to almost $70,000 in the bull market, and come back to $20,000.

Some creditors might want to hold. 

(6/7)

For example, a major bitcoin miner reportedly sold around $300m worth of bitcoin last month at around $23,000 / BTC.

That didn't necessarily cause a black swan event. Far from it. 

In fact, many will agree the main reason why crypto went down was due to poor macro. 

(5/7)

Second, yes, there could be billions of dollars worth of bitcoin thrown into the market.

But there are also billions that gets thrown into the market A LOT. Namely, by bitcoin miners.

We underestimate how the crypto market absorbs sell-side pressure. 

(4/7)

Firstly, we underestimate how much of Mt. Gox bitcoin were probably sold over-the-counter at pennies on the dollar.

Creditors thought they couldn't get access to these funds for many years and probably sold some of them.

The final amount probably wouldn't be $3 billion. 

(3/7)

Mt. Gox was once the biggest bitcoin exchange in crypto. It got insolvent, and billions worth of crypto got locked in years-long bankruptcy proceedings.

These crypto assets, worth $3 billion, could soon reportedly unlock.

However, it shouldn't worry you too much imo.

As scaling solutions develop and as younger people turn to crypto, I think games like Axie and ChainGuardians will gain traction.

It makes sense, too: as crypto grows, the opportunity to make money by gaming in crypto grows.

In the case of Axie Infinity, the $AXS token is used for staking, as a means of payment, and as a governance mechanism for the game. 

In the case of ChainGuardians, $CGG token has a similar function, to be used as a way to accrue value from the growth of the game.

While these NFT games remind me of my childhood, there's also an opportunity to monetize the gameplay.

Think of this like CS:GO skins on steroids, where playing the game can actually net you earnings.

A comparable platform is Axie Infinity $AXS, which has incorporated their NFTs into various gamified platforms in a similar fashion with significant success. (I also invested in Axie) https://t.co/KRN16K4OIk

One project that I am particularly excited about is ChainGuardians (of which I am an investor).

The project takes traditional gaming concepts like role-playing and PVP and integrates their NFTs, with each one having unique traits, abilities, rarity, etc. https://t.co/B3cRIeGsNs

But what‚Äôs next for this trend?

I believe that the NFTs with clear value and utility will be the next segment of this market to take off.

Unlike in the summer, NFTs are now gaining mainstream adoption, with major news outlets like CNBC and providing coverage of the craze, and billionaire investors like Mark Cuban and Chamath all participating.

Celebrities have been cashing in on it as well.

The downturn throughout the fall months led interest in NFTs to wane, but the recent bull run combined with the launch of new consumer-oriented products like NBA Top Shot has revived the trend, and it‚Äôs now stronger than ever.

NFTs have existed for quite some time (think CryptoKitties), but they only started gaining widespread traction within the crypto space recently.

My opinion is that ‚ÄúDeFi summer‚Äù led early investors to ‚Äúdiversify‚Äù their portfolios by directing funds towards digital artwork.

I'm not sure about you guys but I grew up playing Pokemon trading cards and playing Pokemon on my Gameboy.

While I'm not into art NFTs, I've been increasingly interested in NFT projects focused on gaming like Axie Infinity and ChainGuardians.

So here is a project that checks all the boxes: a great product primed for mass adoption, an experienced all star team and advisors, increasing TVL, and a roadmap with major developments to come!

It should also be noted that $VSP has some serious backers and advisors incl. Robert Leshner (Compound), Meltem Demirors (Coinshare), Ryan Selkis (Messari), Qiao Wang (Defi Alliance) & Ian Lee (IDEO Colab Ventures)

In terms of governance roadmap, starting 6m from launch (so August 2021) the governance voting rights will start progressively being transferred from the team to VSP token holders so that by 12m later (Aug 2022), the project will be fully governed by the community.
VSP has some serious room to grow, especially considering that the current Grow Pool products on Vesper are only the first of many, and that L2 integration and Earn Pools will be arriving soon.

Now why do I think $VSP is so undervalued? Let‚Äôs compare TVL and market caps for other yield aggregator projects:
$YFI has $337M TVL and $1.2bn Mcap (1.25bn fully diluted)
$ALPHA has $695M TVL and $409M Mcap  (1.4bn fully dil)
$VSP has $340M TVL and $39M Mcap (270M fully dil)

Max Supply is 10M tokens, with 65% going to the community (Incentivized Launch Pools, LP incentives, and project Reserves) and 35% for the team, advisors, and strategic partners with a 12 twelve month vesting.

The platform charges fees of 15% of pool profits + 0.6% withdrawing fees and 95% of these fees are used to buyback $VSP from the market and distribute as staking rewards to $VSP stakes. This means strong upward price pressure and potentially large revenues for stakers.

Now let‚Äôs talk tokens. $VSP is the native Vesper platform token, with two major utilities: governance voting and earning platform fee revenues through staking rewards. Tokens can currently be earned by using Vesper Pools, Liquidity Mining (on Sushi and Uni) and Staking.

The short term roadmap also includes the integration of ETH L2 solutions and other chains for scalability + reduced fees (xDAi and Avalanche are being considered), and a Vesper Earn product where users can chose to invest asset A (eg. ETH) but earn yield on asset B (eg. USDC)

This professional and conservative approach, along with user friendly products where all complexity is abstracted away, is how Vesper will seek to reach mainstream adoption. And with $340M in TVL barely 8 days after official launch, the strategy seems to be working!

Another seemingly minor feature that greatly improves user experience is that Vesper implemented EIP-2612 across all platform tokens, which means there is no need for a separate gas consuming transaction to ‚Äúapprove‚Äù each token before they can be transferred.

And the multi pool approach means that each user-facing Vesper Grow Pool is a ‚Äúfront pool‚Äù while funds may be deployed to different ‚Äúback pools‚Äù, each with different strategies and risk profiles, allowing for better flexibility and risk diversification for the users‚Äô funds.

Its modular architecture means that pools can easily transition between investment strategies without requiring smart contract upgrades or maintenance. This allows pools to easily switch strategies to reach the highest available yields, with no friction for the end user.

Similar to other existing yield aggregators, Vesper allocates pool funds to different DeFi platforms (such as Compound, Aave, Maker‚Ä¶) in order to maximize yield based on different investment strategies. But Vesper‚Äôs solution stands out for its modular and multi-pool approach.

Vesper‚Äôs first product is an extremely user friendly ‚Äúset and forget‚Äù yield aggregator, allowing users to deposit USDC,DAI,ETH or WBTC into Grow Pools and earn yield on their deposits. But behind the apparent simplicity, there is a lot of hidden innovation.

Vesper‚Äôs aim is to build a platform for easy to use DeFi products that will bridge the gap between the dynamism and ‚Äútest in prod‚Äù approach of the existing DeFi space and the professionalism and ease of use necessary for DeFi to reach mainstream adoption.

The project‚Äôs co-founders are former bitcoin core dev Jeff Garzik (Jeff was working with Satoshi himself since 2010) and Matthew Roszak, both also co-founders of leading blockchain infrastructure company @bloqinc.

We interviewed the Perpetual Protocol team on Alpha Alarm.

For an in-depth talk about the platform and $PERP, have a read. (6/6)

https://t.co/p0c79AYldF

Key technologies?

- Transaction mining: incentivizing traders with a portion of fees
- Virtual AMMs: algorithmically provide lower slippage (5/6)

Perpetual Protocol is based on xDai, a layer two scaling solution. 

This makes it cheap to process trades and withdraw funds.

"xDai Network is one of the few scaling solutions that really work today." - co-founder Yenwen Feng. (4/6)

Perpetual Protocol is generating about $611,000 from fees per month (0.1%). 

So, it is generating around *$7.3 million per year.* 

$PERP is currently valued at $101 million, with an FDV of $742 million.

$101M/$7.3M = 13x the revenue. Not bad. (3/6)

Perpetual Protocol is a decentralized perpetual futures exchange.

It allows up to 20x leverage, with lower slippage than other automated market makers (AMMs).

It collects 0.1% fee on trades, which makes it cash flow positive. (2/6)

I‚Äôll be writing more about crypto in Asia through tweet threads and also on my newsletter. For the full article, read below!

https://t.co/IBYp4WDFSu

(10/10)

One positive development is that the shady exchanges in South Korea subsided.

There are now about 10 major exchanges operating in Korea. The crypto exchange landscape is simpler and much better regulated.

So if retail frenzy begins, overall confidence will be higher.

(9/10)

But, there is a roadblock.

The sentiment around crypto in general in South Korea remains gloomy.

People are opening to Bitcoin more, but the pain of 2017 is still there.

The retail volume is pretty much dead in South Korea too [a tweet thread is coming this week].

(8/10)

Many prominent investment firms have shown interest in the potential of massive consumer crypto adoption in South Korea.

Binance Labs, OKEx, Huobi Capital, Dunamu, Polychain Capital, FBG Capital, Hashed, ArringtonXRP Capital invested in Terra.

(7/10)

South Korea‚Äôs most famous star chef Choi Hyun Suk‚Äôs restaurant also accepts crypto as payment.

This is a direct partnership with a blockchain company with a specialized cryptocurrency, so I won‚Äôt mention the name.

And, this is becoming a trend.

https://t.co/621868btxR

(6/10) https://t.co/FppXDTFd6L

Yanolja is the biggest hotel booking platform in South Korea with over 1 million users.

Yanolja also integrated Chai in September 2019, which means users can pay crypto to book rooms on Yanolja.

So it's possible to live off of crypto in Korea, unlike most countries.

(5/10) https://t.co/O4HESalymc

The brilliance of using Chai as the partner for all these major retailers, like CU, is that they aren‚Äôt directly integrating crypto assets like $BTC or $ETH.

They are integrating Chai, which accepts crypto assets, so companies like CU do not have any major problems.

(4/10)

How is this gigantic convenience chain accepting crypto?

The firm/blockchain in the middle of this is Terra.

Terra is a payments firm co-founded by e-commerce giant Tmon creator Shin Hyunseung.

Terra has a blockchain and payments app Chai, which major retailers accept.

(3/10)

First, let's look at pure retail consumer adoption. 

South Korea has tens of thousands of convenience stores nationwide. 

Like Taiwan and Japan, convenience stores are absolutely massive in Korea.

Users can pay crypto at 13,500 CU convenience stores in South Korea.

(2/10) https://t.co/C5ZFnuvgiy

A thread!

I believe South Korea might be the first to see real *MASSIVE* mainstream consumer adoption of crypto.

There are many things people don't know about crypto in South Korea, and I will be working on more threads about crypto in Asia in the future.

@popcornazerty A futures contract that doesn't expire is called a perpetual swap contract.

Since there is no expiration, buyers and sellers have to pay a "funding rate" every 8 hours. If the market is majority long, then longs or buyers pay shorts or short-sellers.
@krugermacro indeed, also funding rates can change quite quickly. IE, predicted funding rate often isn't as high as it shows

In short, while 2020's bitcoin halving is met with a substantial decline in price from $10k, miners are not in as big of a trouble as they seem.

Mining execs expect the industry to expand over the medium-term, especially if bitcoin price starts to climb.

F2Pool co-founder Mao Shixing said that big bitcoin miners in China are able to find cheap electricity to operate mining centers with lower costs.

If mining difficulty drops and miners can keep cost of mining down, even with low price, resourceful miners will survive.

There will be short-term drop in bitcoin hash rate after the halving.

But, Poolin VP Alejandro De La Torre @bitentrepreneur said  that after the halving, miners are more clearly able to predict their revenues over the next 4 years, and it will lead to mining expansion. https://t.co/Lby53QuFo9

One thing many people are not aware of is that it is now cheaper to mine bitcoin than before.

There are better professional custody service providers and mining center construction firms that make it easy for small miners to mine.

Hence, small miners may not capitulate as much.

If BTC says at $6k~$7k, more mining equipment will be shut down, said F2Pool co-founder Mao Shixing.

The bitcoin price will be significantly below the cost of mining BTC. As a result, more miners will close down in the short-term. https://t.co/Je9bwxQdby

I spoke to the co-founder / executive of two largest bitcoin mining pools in the world F2Pool and Poolin to talk about how the mining industry would look after the halving.
